title: Could The Batman be as dark as Joker?
text:
Could Robert Pattinson’s The Batman share the tone of Joker? (Picture: Warner Bros; Rex)

***Joker Spoilers Ahead***

The film on everyone’s mind at the moment is Joker. Whether you loved or hated Todd Phillips’ dark take on Batman’s greatest foe, it’s top of the box office and has everyone talking about what’s next for the world of DC. Phillips and others have maintained that Joker is a standalone film, not intended to have any sequel or tie to the DC Extended Universe.

However… this is Hollywood. Plans can change very quickly, particularly if a certain way of working proves to be profitable. The door has certainly been left open for a connection to Matt Reeves’ The Batman – the closing moments of the film saw the fabled murder of Thomas and Martha Wayne, while reports that The Batman will be set in The ’90s would work with Joker’s early 80’s setting.

Advertisement

But could an adult-oriented Batman be possible? Following a decade of Marvel dominance, could DC find a way to compete with the Avengers juggernaut by marketing themselves to an older audience, out for something darker than the average blockbuster can provide?

Bringing a level of R-Rated grit to the world of Batman would be a lot easier than most characters. Many of the comics have featured grisly murders or assaults, while some of Batman’s adventures in animation and video games have gone further than his PG movie equivalents have been allowed to. The very first Batman comic featured The Caped Crusader hanging a criminal in mid-air. On the big screen, Christopher Nolan’s Dark Knight Trilogy featured a degree of realism unmatched by most comic book movies, but to push the boundaries that Phillips and Joaquin Phoenix pushed in Joker would involve a shift that would be unusual in Hollywood.

Batman films have walked a fine line when it comes to violence – Heath Ledger’s Joker impaled a man’s head on a pencil in The Dark Knight, while Ben Affleck breaks Batman’s long-held ‘no killing’ rule in Batman V Superman. However, these scenes were shot in such a way that the violence was either off-screen at a crucial moment, or bloodless.

Joaquin’s Joker showed gruesome, detailed deaths (Picture: Warner Bros.)

Joker features very gruesome, detailed deaths, and it’s not just about the blood. Aside from the violence, the film also tackles issues of mental illness and child abuse. Would we see Robert Pattinson grapple with PTSD, or beat a suspect to a gruesome pulp prompted by past trauma? We’ve seen Bruce Wayne deal with his issues in a very PG way in films like Batman Forever, but to go deep inside the mind of someone with as harrowing an origin story would be risky in an industry that wants to market films to as wide an audience as possible.

Advertisement

It’s one thing to experiment with The Joker, a character who can be rebooted very quickly (just ask Jared Leto), but not with a character the studios will be hoping to make billion-dollar box office from. That said, with Aquaman becoming the most successful DC movie ever last year, maybe he and Wonder Woman will be the family-friendly crowd-pleasers while DC goes in a more cerebral direction with their most famous title.

Whether The Batman is unconnected to Joker, follows its themes closely, or (most likely) has a loose connection in terms of timeline, there’s one thing Reeves would be wise to adhere to. However gruesome things get, Batman can’t be the one doing the killing. Ben Affleck’s body count in Batman V Superman drew criticism from purists, who argue that the vow to never kill is at the core of who the character has become over the years. However unsettling things get in Gotham, that’s one rule many fans would hate to see broken.

description: We look at the likelihood of The Batman being as hard-hitting as Todd Phillips' new hit.
